So for Allah, glorified be He, in the hearts (Qulub) and spirits (Arwah) and other worlds are mustered hosts whose reality and detailed number none knows except Him. And we now point to some of the hosts of the heart (Qalb), for that relates to our purpose. It has two hosts: a host seen with the eyes and a host seen only with the insights (Basa'ir). It is in the position of the king, and the hosts are in the position of servants and helpers. This is the meaning of host. As for its host witnessed with the eye, it is the hand, the leg, the eye, the ear, the tongue, and the rest of the apparent and hidden organs, for all of them are servants to the heart (Qalb) and subjugated to it. It is the one disposing them and turning them. They were created molded to obey it, unable to oppose it or rebel against it. If it commands the eye to open, it opens; if it commands the leg to move, it moves; if it commands the tongue to speak and decides the judgment with it, it speaks, and likewise the rest of the organs. ğŸ“– Vol 3: Condemnation of Pride and Conceit
If you say: Indeed, he (peace be upon him) said after his statement to Fatimah and Safiyyah, "I cannot avail you anything from Allah except that you have kinship ties which I will fulfill with their due," and he (peace and blessings be upon him) said, "Do you hope, Salim, for my intercession (Shafa'ah) while the sons of Abd al-Muttalib do not hope for it?" Does that indicate that he will specifically grant his relatives intercession (Shafa'ah)? Know that every Muslim is awaiting the intercession (Shafa'ah) of the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him), and the relative is also worthy of hoping for it, but on the condition that he guards against Allah's anger upon him, for if He is angry with him, then He does not permit anyone to intercede (Shafa'ah) for him. This is because sins are divided into those that necessitate wrath, so intercession (Shafa'ah) is not permitted for them, and those that are forgiven due to intercession (Shafa'ah), like sins with worldly kings, for every person of status with the king cannot intercede (Shafa'ah) in matters where the king's anger is severe. Thus, among sins are those from which intercession (Shafa'ah) does not save, and about this is the expression in His saying, "Nor will they intercede (Yashfa'una) except for whom He approves," and in His saying, "Who is it that can intercede (Yashfa'u) with Him except by His permission?" and in His saying, "And intercession (Shafa'ah) does not benefit with Him except for whom He permits," and in His saying, "So their intercession (Shafa'ah) of the intercessors (Shafi'in) will not benefit them." And when sins are divided into those in which intercession (Shafa'ah) is granted and those in which it is not, fear and apprehension are inevitably obligatory. If there were a sin in which intercession (Shafa'ah) is accepted, He would not have commanded the Quraysh to obey, nor would the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) have prohibited Fatimah (may Allah be pleased with her) from disobedience, and He would have permitted her to follow desires to complete her self in this world, then intercede (Shafa'ah) for her in the Hereafter to complete her self in the Hereafter.
